items.title: A big update for ECharts
items.content:
#â€‹676 â€” February 22, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ“ŠÂ Apache ECharts 5.5: The Powerful Visualization Library â€” EChartsâ€™ big selling point, beyond being a well supported Apache-backed project, is its balance of power and simplicity. You can do a lot with it (check out the many examples here) without the code becoming complex. v5.5 enhances its ESM support, adds server-side rendering support, and lets you make incomplete pieÂ charts.

Apache Software Foundation

ğŸ’Œ If you need to be convinced further, check out Alice GG's Love Letter to ApacheÂ ECharts.

ğŸ“£Â The React Team Shares What It's Been Working On â€” Work on React Compiler has progressed with it now powering Instagramâ€™s prod site ('React 19 Will Be Compiled' goes into depth on what the compiler means for most React devs). We also learn React 19 is on the way and will include breaking changes to support things like WebÂ Components.

The React.js Core Team

Register for POST/CON 24! Coming April 30-MayÂ 1 â€” Join hundreds of developers in San Francisco on April 30 and May 1 for hands-on API workshops, presentations from industry leaders, and a big reveal of Postman productÂ updates.

Postman sponsor

Redwood v7.0: The React + GraphQL App Framework â€” Redwood is a full-stack Web framework that takes an opinionated approach, bringing together React, GraphQL, Prisma, and TypeScript, with a focus on building complete apps rapidly. v7 includes a new observability tool called Redwood Studio, realtime GraphQL features, andÂ more.

RedwoodJS Community

Node.js's 2023 Summarized â€” Rafael, of the Node.js TSC and Fastify core team, shares a useful update on the evolution of Node.js over the past year, how the team ensures Node is well tested and reliable, changes to Nodeâ€™s vendor dependencies (of which it gained three in 2023), as well as enhancements to Nodeâ€™s security and WebÂ presence.

Rafael Gonzaga

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¢Â The Node.js project has unveiled Rocket Turtle, its new mascot!

  • 1 in 5 of the most popular, 'high impact' packages on npm now includeÂ ESM.

  • ğŸ‘¾ A 'Frogger' game in 256 bytes? Yes, really. Be sure to ViewÂ Source.

  • A visualization of Math.random() distributions of variousÂ kinds.

  • The Deno team has revamped its onboarding tutorials for Deno Deploy, if you want to experiment with JavaScript at the edge.

RELEASES:

  • Bun 1.0.28 â€“ Mostly a bugfix/stabilityÂ release.

  • Puppeteer 22.2 â€“ Control Chrome with Node.js. Now on Chrome 122.

  • Deno 1.41, Rollup 4.12.0, Jest Puppeteer 10.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

A Guide to Using localStorage in Modern Apps â€” localStorage has been supported in most browsers for fifteen years plus now, so itâ€™s a reliable way to store data client-side, though there are still situations where you wouldnâ€™t want to use it. A good primer, but with a focus on alternativeÂ options.

RxDB Project

How to Set Up a Basic Node Server App with TypeScript in 2024 â€” Popular dev educator Jason with a quick tutorial on how to set up a modern Node project with TypeScript, live reloading, and loading in environmentÂ variables.

Jason Lengstorf

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” Userfront is an auth & identity platform that transforms your business to serve free, freemium and enterpriseÂ customers.

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â Pac-Man in JavaScript in 1 Hour â€” I felt old when Ania said â€œif youâ€™ve never played Pac-Man before..â€ ğŸ˜… â€“ nonetheless, sheâ€™s back with another of her fantastic, thoroughÂ walkthroughs.

Ania KubÃ³w

HTMX vs React: A Complete Comparison â€” It strikes me as tricky to compare two very different approaches to what will often be distinct use cases, but undoubtedly people will want to weigh them up against each other, so here youÂ go.

Antonello Zanini and Dan Ackerson

How Qwik Differs From React Hydration â€” Qwik works quite differently to the ReactÂ approach.

Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

An Ultimate Vim Vue Setup â€” How to set up Vue/Nuxt autocompletion forÂ Vim/Neovim.
Nikola Äuza

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Perspective 2.8: Fast Streaming Data Visualization via WebAssembly â€” A data visualization component, well-suited for large and/or streaming datasets, that can be used from both JavaScript and Python. Itâ€™s been fun watching this library improve over the past couple of years. The docs have been improved a lot. GitHubÂ repo.

Perspective Authors

Hookdeck: The Amazon EventBridge Alternative â€” Receive, send, and route messages across your event-driven applications with an event gateway for engineeringÂ teams.

Hookdeck sponsor

Vuestic Admin: A Vue 3 Admin Template â€” A recently redesigned, modern admin template using Vue 3, Vite, Pinia, and Tailwind CSS. Check out the live demo or GitHubÂ repo.

Epicmax LLC

ğŸ—“Â Tommy's Inclusive Datepicker: A Human-Friendly Date Picker â€” Try out this Web Component on the homepage itself. The user can type natural language phrases like â€œNext Fridayâ€ or â€œin 30 daysâ€ and the picker will move to the correct date. GitHubÂ repo.

Tommy Feldt

Skeleton: Reactive, Accessible Svelte UI Toolkit â€” A cool feature of the homepage is you can try out the different built-in themes, including dark and light modes, using a drop-down at theÂ top.

Skeleton Labs

Dax: Cross-Platform Shell Tools for Node â€” Similar to Google's zx but uses a cross-platform shell with common built-in commands so more code will work across platforms. Dax was originally written for Deno but now supports NodeÂ too.

David Sherret

js-tokens 9.0: A Tiny JavaScript Tokenizer â€” A regex-powered â€˜almost spec-compliantâ€™ JavaScriptÂ tokenizer.

Simon Lydell

A Sudoku Solver Implemented in the TypeScript Type System? â€” An appropriate use of the ğŸ¤¯ emojiÂ here, IÂ think!

Roy Li

Save 30% on Your POST/CON Ticket â€” Time is running out to save 30% on POST/CON 24. Don't miss out on Postmanâ€™s biggest user conferenceÂ ever.

Postman sponsor

  • Forge 7.3 â€“ Quickly scaffold an Electron project with full buildÂ pipeline.

  • eslint-plugin-check-file 2.7 â€“ Enforce consistent file/folderÂ naming.

  • React Native Boilerplate 4.1 â€“ A starter template for RNÂ apps.

  • React Uploady 1.8 â€“ Components and hooks for fileÂ uploading.

  • d3-graphviz 5.3 â€“ Graphviz DOT rendering and animatedÂ transitions.

  • ğŸ“± React Native Vision Camera 3.9 â€“ Powerful cameraÂ control.

  • âˆ Peaks.js 3.3 â€“ BBC-created audio waveform UIÂ component.

  • AdminJS 7.6 â€“ Automatic admin interface for NodeÂ apps.

items.title: TC39 adds a new stage for ECMAScript proposals
items.content:
#â€‹675 â€” February 15, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Tempo: An Easier Way to Work with Dates â€” We think they nailed their own summary: â€œA collection of utilities for working with the native Date object â€” an important distinction from other libraries that provide custom date primitives. Under the hood, Tempo mines Intl.DateTimeFormat to extract complex data like timezones offsets and locale aware date formats, giving you a simple API to format, parse, and manipulate dates.â€ Fantastic docs,Â too.

FormKit

LLRT (Low Latency Runtime): Amazon's New JSÂ Runtime â€” Amazon has open sourced a runtime entirely focused on fast startups â€“ something thatâ€™s useful for ephemeral use cases like serverless (*cough* AWS Lambda). It uses Fabrice Bellardâ€™s QuickJS as the underlying engine, so has almost full ES2023 spec support out of theÂ box.

Amazon Web Services Labs

Effortless GraphQL with Hasura and TypeScript Functions â€” Hasura connects to your data sources, generates a GraphQL API, and deploys it globally â€” instantly. But, what if you could also write and use TypesScript functions directly in your GraphQL API? With Hasura, you can. Check it out onÂ GitHub.

Hasura sponsor

The Node.js Valentine's Day Security Releases â€” Security releases had been expected to land in the past week for Node and theyâ€™re now here as v21.6.2 (Current), v20.11.1 (LTS), and v18.19.1 (LTS). They include fixes for a variety of vulnerabilities, including some high severity ones involving HTTP-based DoS attacks and privilegeÂ escalation.

Rafael Gonzaga and Marco Ippolito

IN BRIEF:

  • You know how features and proposals for the ECMAScript language pass through a multi-stage process with the TC39 committee? There's a new stage: stage 2.7! The new stage is what 3 used to be with 3 now having extra testingÂ requirements.

  • Talking of TC39, here's the latest state of different proposals covered at the recent 100th TC39Â meeting.

  • There have been some updates on the state of Express and suggested plans for Express 5.0, 6.0 andÂ 7.0.

  • Google has unveiled the newest version of its Gemini AI model. Of particular note is its support for 1 million tokens of context, as shown in â–¶ï¸ this example working upon the entirety of three.js's source code (~820kÂ tokens).

  • A new JavaScript registry is on the way called jsr. Waitlist only, forÂ now.

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Vue.js DevTools 6.6 â€“ Now with a new UI.

  • Hono 4.0 â€“ The lightweight, runs-anywhere Web framework takes a big stepÂ forward.

  • JointJS 4.0 â€“ The powerful interactive diagramming/flowchart library now has no externalÂ dependencies.

  • Astro 4.4, Angular 17.2, Billboard.js 3.11

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Union, Intersection, Difference, and More Coming to JavaScript Sets â€” Set was introduced back in ECMAScript 2015 (a.k.a. ES6) but only had some basic methods built-in. Phil looks at what sets can do and what new features are on theÂ way.

Phil Nash

Immutable Array Updates with Array.prototype.with â€” How to use this new, widely supported method to update an array without mutating the originalÂ array.

Jad Joubran

Intro to Error and Performance Monitoring with Sentry â€” Track, trace, debug and resolve JavaScript errors across platforms. Are your releases that easy? Join usÂ live.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â So You Think You Know Git.. â€” GitHub co-founder Scott Chacon gave a spirited talk at FOSDEM 2024 digging into many interesting parts of git, as well as a few GitHub bits. If youâ€™d prefer to read rather than watch, he has some blog posts covering it allÂ too.

Scott Chacon

An Example of Creating a React App with Google Sheets as aÂ Backend â€” Not as unorthodox an approach as you mightÂ think.

Musthaq Ahamad

Safely Accessing the DOM with Angular SSR â€” Learn how to safely use the DOM together with SSR inÂ Angular.

Gerald Monaco (Google)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Peggy 4.0: A Parser Generator for JavaScript â€” Produces fast parsers with good error reporting. Use it to process complex data or computer languages and build transformers, interpreters, compilers, and similar tools. The online demo is pretty effective. The official successor to PEG.js.

Majda, Hildebrand, and Contributors

vue-metamorph 1.0: A Codemod Framework for Vue.js Projects â€” A developer needed to make a large number of small changes to a variety of Vue components and built this tool to help. GitHubÂ repo.

UnrefinedBrain

canvas-size 2.0: Determine Max Area, Height, Width, and Custom Dimensions of HTML Canvases â€” The Canvas element is broadly supported across browsers but there are differences in its size limitations, which this library can determine for you. GitHubÂ repo.

John Hildenbiddle

Securing Your APIs: Verifying API Keys And Using Scopes â€” You have APIs. You need to make sure you know who is calling them and what they can do. What are yourÂ options?

FusionAuth sponsor

txiki.js: A Small Yet Powerful JavaScript Runtime â€” Standing on the shoulders of QuickJS andÂ libuv.

SaÃºl Ibarra CorretgÃ©

Svelte Stepper: Build Animated Stepped Flows with Svelte â€” You can add and customize props on the component to adjust the number of steps and transition duration, among other features. See a simple but neat demoÂ here.

Jason Efstathiou

  • ğŸ™ˆ NSFW.js 3.0 â€“ Client-side NSFW image detection viaÂ TensorFlow.js.

  • ğŸ—“ React Big Calendar 1.10 â€“ GCal/Outlook-like calendarÂ component.

  • Tedious 17.0 â€“ TDS module for connecting to Microsoft SQLÂ Server.

  • Inspire Tree 7.0 â€“ Perf-driven headless treeÂ component.

  • Heat.js 2.1 â€“ Render customizable heatÂ maps.

  • Mineflayer 4.19 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

  • Spacetime 7.6 â€“ Lightweight timezoneÂ library.

  • React Tags 6.9 â€“ TaggingÂ component.

items.title: Gorillas
items.content:
#â€‹674 â€” February 8, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

jQuery 4.0.0 Beta â€” I recently looked at issue #1 of JavaScript Weekly and the top two items were jQuery, so itâ€™s nice to feature it :-) You might not be using jQuery, but it's still everywhere, including WordPress. v4 says goodbye to IE 10 support, removes lots of deprecated APIs, and steps into the modern world just a tad (it even migrated toÂ ESM).

jQuery Foundation

ğŸ‰ jQuery isn't the only blast from the past to get an update this week â€“ Backbone.js 1.6 is outÂ too! Let's party like it'sÂ 2014? (Also, ğŸ¦ Vue.js has just turned ten years old!)

â–¶Â Â Reimplementing GORILLAS.BAS in JavaScript â€” My first experience of publishing programming content was in the DOS QBasic era, so I have a soft spot for the Gorillas game that came with QBasic. Hunor has recorded a spectacular screencast on reimplementing it in JavaScript, but if you don't like videos, thereâ€™s a detailed written tutorial,Â too.

Hunor MÃ¡rton BorbÃ©ly

POST/CON 2024 Is Coming! April 30th-May 1st â€” Postmanâ€™s biggest API conference ever is coming, and early registration is now open! Hear from industry leaders and level up your skills in hands-on workshops with Postman experts. Register by February 13, 2024, to get a 50% discount on yourÂ ticket.

Postman sponsor

Node.js Developers Debate Enabling Corepack by Default and Potentially Unbundling npm â€” Node developers are wrestling with the decision to enable Corepack (a tool for managing package managers) by default, which has sparked a debate about the possibility of removing npm from the Node.jsÂ binary.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

â–¶Â Â How to Make A Great Framework Better? - Svelte 5 with Rich Harris â€” A sit-down interview with Rich Harris, creator of Svelte and SvelteKit. Dives into the philosophy, features, and future of Svelte, and covers how it aims to simplify web dev and make apps faster through its build time compilation approach. (78Â minutes)

Prismic

ğŸ¤” If you haven't got time for the interview (above), enjoy Tenets, Rich's attempt to articulate Svelte'sÂ philosophy.

IN BRIEF:

  • Andy Jiang and Ryan Dahl of the Deno project bring us up to speed with how Deno developed in 2023 and hint at the next steps to DenoÂ 2.

  • The New Stack's Richard MacManus caught up with Remix CEO Michael Jackson to talk about the role of Remix and Next.js in the context of the React frameworkÂ ecosystem.

  • ğŸ™ Dan Abramov was recently interviewed on the PodRocket podcast, if you want to catch up with what he'sÂ thinking.

  • Some Node.js security releases are expected to land today, including fixes for four high-severity issues.Â ğŸ¤

  • ğŸ“Š The results of the latest State of React Native survey are out.

RELEASES:

  • Capacitor 5.7 â€“ Build cross-platform native apps withÂ JS.

  • Commander.js 12.0 â€“ Node.js CLI appÂ framework.

  • Million 3.0 â€“ Optimizing compiler for React.

  • Vite 5.1, Bun 1.0.26, Mermaid 10.8, Quill 2.0-rc0

Save 50% on Your POST/CON Ticket â€” Gain new skills through hands-on workshops, in-depth presentations, and conversations at POST/CONÂ 2024.

Postman sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Static Roots: Objects with Compile-Time Constant Addresses â€” The V8 blog never disappoints when it comes to deep, technical posts! Olivier FlÃ¼ckiger of the V8 team explains how fundamental, base objects like undefined and true are made more efficient and live in their own read-only heap. A brief look at the sort of thing that makes V8Â fast!

Olivier FlÃ¼ckiger (V8)

From Many to One: Moving Our JavaScript Code Into a Monorepo â€” A story of trying to reduce complexity, by way of Nx, pnpm workspaces and, eventually, Turborepo. â€œIt justÂ works!â€

JosÃ© Guerrero (Aha!)

Intro to JavaScript Error and Performance Monitoring with Sentry â€” Track, trace, debug and resolve JavaScript errors across platforms. Are your releases that easy? Join usÂ live.

Sentry sponsor

Creating an Animated 3D Starfield / 'Warp Speed' Effect â€” Itâ€™s always fun to get into some simple visual stuff like this every now andÂ then. (This whole site is filled with interesting little tutorials, likeÂ this.)

Kirupa Chinnathambi

â–¶Â Â A Deep Dive into htmx â€” Covers the fundamentals, digging into htmxâ€™s codebase â€“ plus itâ€™s an unlisted video so you can feel like youâ€™re in a secretÂ club.

Carson Gross

Detecting Caps Lock from JavaScript
David Walsh

Just Enough CORS to Not Get Stuck
Abin Simon

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Tabulator: An Interactive Table and Data Grid Library â€” Supports all major browsers and can be used with Angular, Vue, and React if you wish. Been around for several years now, but continues to beÂ maintained.

Oli Folkerd

ğŸ¥½ Â React Native for Apple Vision Pro â€” â€œUnlike compatibility mode, this approach allows immersive experiences and XR features on visionOS.â€ Now you just need to find $3500+ to buy the VisionÂ Pro..Â ;-)

Oskar KwaÅ›niewski (Callstack)

Open-Source JavaScript UI Components to Create Forms and Convert Them to PDF â€” Create and edit dynamic JSON-based forms with a self-hosted drag-and-drop form builder. Render them as editable PDFs directly in yourÂ browser.

SurveyJS sponsor

React Native TypeScript Boilerplate â€” Unsurprisingly, this is an all-in-one starter/boilerplate React Native app that uses TypeScript. It also includes a theming system, icons, Husky integration, and more, to help you get startedÂ fast.

FreakyCoder

Marked.js 12.0: Fast Markdown Parsing and Compiling â€” A low-level Markdown compiler built for speed and available as a client-side library, server-side library, or CLI. v12 brings it in line with recent CommonMarkÂ updates.

Christopher Jeffrey

Storybook 8 Beta â€” The latest update to the popular UI component workshop has improvements a-plenty including faster startup times, React Server Components support, as well as support for Vite 5 and LitÂ 3.

Michael Shilman (Storybook)

react-native-live-markdown: A Cross-Platform Markdown Editor â€” A drop-in replacement for React Nativeâ€™s TextInput component but with MarkdownÂ formatting.

Expensify, Inc

Vue Currency Input: Currency Formatted Number Inputs for Vue.js â€” Based on Intl.NumberFormat and sitting atop the Vue Composition API, you can use this to decorate any input component with currency formattingÂ capabilities.

Matthias Stiller

  • âœ‚ï¸ Knip 4.5 â€“ Cut unused files and exports from JS/TSÂ projects.

  • NVM Desktop 3.0 â€“ Desktop UI for Node VersionÂ Manager.

  • Puppeteer Replay 3.0 â€“ Replay recordings from Chrome DevToolsÂ Recorder.

  • React Date Picker 6.1 â€“ Simple date picker component.Â (Demo.)

  • ğŸ“Š gridstack.js 10.1 â€“ Build responsive interactive dashboardsÂ quickly.

  • query-string 8.2 â€“ Parse and stringify URL queryÂ strings.

  • ml.js 7.0 â€“ Machine learning tools forÂ JavaScript.

  • SWC 1.4 â€“ Rust-based tooling for the Web.
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹674 â€” February 8, 2024


Read on the Web




    
    

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
jQuery 4.0.0 Beta â€” I recently looked at issue #1 of JavaScript Weekly and the top two items were jQuery, so itâ€™s nice to feature it :-) You might not be using jQuery, but it's still everywhere, including WordPress. v4 says goodbye to IE 10 support, removes lots of deprecated APIs, and steps into the modern world just a tad (it even migrated toÂ ESM).
jQuery Foundation 


ğŸ‰ jQuery isn't the only blast from the past to get an update this week â€“ Backbone.js 1.6 is outÂ too! Let's party like it'sÂ 2014? (Also, ğŸ¦ Vue.js has just turned ten years old!)





  
  
â–¶Â Â Reimplementing GORILLAS.BAS in JavaScript â€” My first experience of publishing programming content was in the DOS QBasic era, so I have a soft spot for the Gorillas game that came with QBasic. Hunor has recorded a spectacular screencast on reimplementing it in JavaScript, but if you don't like videos, thereâ€™s a detailed written tutorial,Â too.
Hunor MÃ¡rton BorbÃ©ly 


  
  
POST/CON 2024 Is Coming! April 30th-May 1st â€” Postmanâ€™s biggest API conference ever is coming, and early registration is now open! Hear from industry leaders and level up your skills in hands-on workshops with Postman experts. Register by February 13, 2024, to get a 50% discount on yourÂ ticket.
Postman sponsor


  
  
Node.js Developers Debate Enabling Corepack by Default and Potentially Unbundling npm â€” Node developers are wrestling with the decision to enable Corepack (a tool for managing package managers) by default, which has sparked a debate about the possibility of removing npm from the Node.jsÂ binary.
Sarah Gooding (Socket) 


  
  
â–¶Â Â How to Make A Great Framework Better? - Svelte 5 with Rich Harris â€” A sit-down interview with Rich Harris, creator of Svelte and SvelteKit. Dives into the philosophy, features, and future of Svelte, and covers how it aims to simplify web dev and make apps faster through its build time compilation approach. (78Â minutes)
Prismic 


ğŸ¤” If you haven't got time for the interview (above),  enjoy Tenets, Rich's attempt to articulate Svelte'sÂ philosophy.

items.title: A Qwik break from React?
items.content:
#â€‹673 â€” February 1, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Cytoscape.js: Graph/Network Visualization and Analysis Library â€” Handy if you need to model and/or visualize relational data, like biological data or social networks. There are many demos to enjoy here. GitHubÂ repo.

Max Franz

Announcing TypeScript 5.4 Beta â€” TypeScript gains Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy, a new NoInfer<T> utility type is introduced to stop TypeScript from digging in to match against inner types during inference, and lots of smaller bits and pieces covered in this lengthy post. The final release is expected inÂ March.

Daniel Rosenwasser

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript DataGrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the grid module. Pick and choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, andÂ Vue.

Wijmo from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Deno 1.40: Now with the Temporal API â€” Most releases of the Deno JS runtime seem significant lately, but 1.40â€™s implementation of the Temporal API, decorators, and more WebGPU features ups the ante on the path toÂ v2.

The Deno Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Some Node.js security releases are anticipated next Tuesday (FebÂ 6.)

  • TIL: The pnpm project maintains a frequently updated benchmark of package managers (well, npm, pnpm and Yarn, anyway.)

  • ğŸ€ Bouncy Ball shows a live comparison of 22 ways to animate a bouncing ball in the browser. Most are JS-based and show theÂ code.

  • Porffor is an experimental, ahead-of-time JS to WASM compiler.

RELEASES:

  • htmx 2.0.0-alpha1 â€“ There's a draft 1.xâ†’2.x migration guide showing what will be affected (not aÂ lot).

  • Puppeteer 21.10.0 â€“ Node.js API for Chrome - now with experimental browser.debugInfo.

  • Neutralinojs 5.0 â€“ Lightweight cross platform desktop appÂ framework.

  • Primate 0.28, Prisma 5.9, Ember 5.6, Pixi.js 7.4

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Take a Qwik Break from React with Astro â€” Paul Scanlon compares React to Qwik using several examples and concludes that Qwik is at least worth exploring as a ReactÂ alternative.

Paul Scanlon

Import Assertions and Import Attributes â€” Shu-yu Guo, of both TC39 and the V8 team at Google, explains how import assertions matured into import attributes and are enabled by default in V8Â v12.3.

Shu-yu Guo (V8)

A Next.js App Router Migration: The Good, Bad, and Ugly â€” A team rebuilt their main dashboard from scratch using a modern Next.js approach and hereâ€™s some of what they encountered, good and bad, before concluding that they wish theyâ€™d considered RemixÂ instead.

Brandon Bayer (Flightcontrol)

Improving Enterprise Design Systems â€” Live stream for design system builders and users: How can we make working with design systems moreÂ seamless?

StackBlitz sponsor

Squeezing the Last Bit of JS Performance for my Automation Game â€” The author is building CivIdle, a casual â€˜idleâ€™ civilization building game, using Pixi.JS. As an idle game, it needs to simulate time that passed behind the scenes which meant a lot of optimization was inÂ order.

Ruoyu Sun

Starting and Publishing a Library: The Modern Way â€” A walk through the steps involved in creating and packaging a library, publishing a package, adding testing, and automatically publishing it all to the NPMÂ registry.

TamÃ¡s Sallai

How to Test Web Bluetooth with Puppeteer â€” Use Puppeteer to test features that use the Web Bluetooth API inÂ Chrome.

Masso and Beaufort

The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Must Know About Unicode â€” A modern extension to a classic 2003 article by JoelÂ Spolsky.
Nikita Prokopov

Tackling Flaky Tests with Cypress and Playwright through Network Synchronization
Shreya Kurian

Why I'm Excited for Biome's Type Inference
Arend van Beelen jr.

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Labyrinthos.js: A Procedural Generator for Mazes, Etc. â€” The interactive demo on the homepage will give you the basic idea, but the library implements a variety of algorithms for creating mazes and terrain, including the use of Perlin noise, growing trees, spiral backtracking, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Yantra Works

The Most Comprehensive User Management Platform â€” Clerk offers drop-in auth & user management with prebuilt UI components, feature-rich SDKs & APIs for the modernÂ web.

Clerk sponsor

React Resizable Panels: Components for ResizableÂ Panels â€” If you want users to be able to resize content panels with dividers, try this. The site has many code-based examples showing off the features. v2 supports resizing multiple intersecting panels at once. GitHubÂ repo.

Brian Vaughn

Husky 9: Git Hooks Made Easier â€” Husky provides a structured way to use git hooks to do things like auto-lint your commit messages or code, and run tests upon committing or pushing. v9 makes setting it up and adding hooks much easier.

typicode

David UI Angular 1.0: Tailwind + Angular Components Libary â€” There are seventeen components so far, covering things like sliders, buttons, notification alerts, and common form elements. GitHubÂ repo.

Creative Tim

React Datepicker 6.0: A Simple Date Picker Component â€” I canâ€™t remember the last time I saw so many code examples on aÂ homepageÂ :-)

HackerOne

ğŸ¹ Fast, Reliable, Multi-Format Barcode Scanning for Web Apps withÂ STRICH â€” Reliably scan barcodes in your web app! Easy integration, free demo app and free 30-dayÂ trial.

Pixelverse sponsor

goja: An ECMAScript/JavaScript Engine in Pure Go(lang) â€” A way to add JavaScript-based scripting functionality to apps written in the Go language that doesnâ€™t involve integrating a larger, external JavaScriptÂ engine.

Dmitry Panov

ğŸ¨Â chroma.js: Zero Dependency Color Conversion Library â€” I love the simple but suitably colorful documentation this library has. GitHubÂ repo.

Gregor Aisch

  • Faker 8.4 â€“ Generate fake/dummy data, at scale and on demand.

  • jquery.terminal 2.38 â€“ Create Web based terminalÂ experiences.Â (Demo.)

  • Polished 4.3 â€“ A lightweight way to write styles inÂ JavaScript.

  • Dependency Cruiser 16.1 â€“ Tool to visualizeÂ dependencies.

  • Nightwatch.js 3.4 â€“ Node.js end-to-end testingÂ framework.

  • OverlayScrollbars 2.5 â€“ JS custom scrollbarÂ plugin.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
